The 1st '''Nepalese Constituent Assembly''' was a [[unicameralism|unicameral]] body of 601 members that served from May 28, 2008 to May 28, 2012. It was formed as a result of the [[Nepalese Constituent Assembly election, 2008|first Constituent Assembly election]] held on April 10, 2008.<ref>Sengupta, Somini. [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/10/world/asia/10nepal.html?em&ex=1207972800&en=fd9aedc6cdf00a8b&ei=5087%0A Polls Open in Nepal the Day After Violence Killed 8]. ''The New York Times''. 2008-04-10.</ref> The Constituent Assembly was tasked with writing a new [[Constitution of Nepal|constitution]],<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7339813.stm Nepal votes in landmark elections]. ''BBC News''. 2008-04-10.</ref> and acting as the interim legislature for a term of two years.<ref>[http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Nepal_Interim_Constitution2007.pdf Interim Constitution of Nepal]</ref> 240 members were elected in single seat constituencies, 335 were elected through proportional representation,<ref>Vijay, Tarun. [http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Tarun_Vijay_Rebirth_of_Nepal/articleshow/2940127.cms Rebirth of Nepal]. ''The Times of India''. 2008-04-10.</ref> and the remaining 26 seats were reserved for nominated members.<ref name="CabAmend">[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun25/news12.php "Cabinet approves constitutional amendment draft"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 25, 2008.</ref>
The [[Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)]] (CPN (M)) was the largest party in the Constituent Assembly, having won half of the constituency seats and about 30% of proportional representation seats.<ref>Mishra, Rabindra. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7360223.stm Nepal: The rocky red road]. ''BBC News''. 2008-04-22.</ref> The Constituent Assembly declared a republic at its first meeting on May 28, 2008, abolishing the [[Nepalese monarchy|monarchy]].<ref name="Fed"/>
In late June 2008, the parties agreed to divide the 26 nominated seats in the Constituent Assembly between nine parties: the CPN (M) was to receive nine of these seats, while the [[Nepali Congress]] (NC) and the [[Communist Party of Nepal (Unified Marxist-Leninist)]] (CPN (UML)) (which respectively placed second and third in the election) would each receive five, the [[Madhesi Janadhikar Forum]] would receive two, and the [[Sadbhavana Party]], the [[Nepal Workers and Peasants Party]], [[Janamorcha Nepal]], and the [[Communist Party of Nepal (Marxist-Leninist)]] would each receive one nominated seat.<ref name="CabAmend"/><ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun27/news01.php "Parties recommend names for 26 CA members"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 27, 2008.</ref> Due to its failure in drafting a new constitution, the CA was dissolved on May 28, 2012 after its original and extended total tenure of 4 years.<ref>[http://ekantipur.com/2012/05/28/top-story/ca-dissolved-pm-proposes-fresh-election-for-nov-22/354644.html ]</ref> The [[Nepalese Constituent Assembly election, 2013|next Nepalese Constituent Assembly elections]] initially slated for November 22, 2012 <ref>[http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article3463109.ece Nepal's CA fails to write Constitution]</ref> were held a year later on November 19, 2013 after being postponed several times.<ref>{{cite news|title=Nepal voting ends for new Constituent Assembly|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-24987573|accessdate=23 January 2014|newspaper=BBC News|date=19 November 2013}}</ref>
==Opening of the Constituent Assembly, declaration of the Republic== The official and final list of members elected under the PR system was released on 8 May 2008; this meant the first meeting of the CA (which has to be held within 21 days of the publication of the final result) would be held before the end of May 2008.<ref>[http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90851/6407152.html "Nepali Election Commission releases names of candidates elected under PR system"], Xinhua (''People's Daily Online''), May 8, 2008.</ref> On 12 May 2008, it was announced that the first session of the CA would be held on 28 May 2008.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7396643.stm "Deadline looms for Nepal's king"], BBC News, May 12, 2008.</ref> The members of the CA were sworn in on 27 May 2008.<ref>[http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5iAPsyovn4rudJdGnD0wOszMda-rg "New Nepal assembly sworn in, set to abolish monarchy"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080531010250/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5iAPsyovn4rudJdGnD0wOszMda-rg |date=2008-05-31 }}, AFP, May 27, 2008.</ref>
The composition of CA looked like this:
[[Image:Constituent Assembly (2008) Composition of Nepal.jpg|700px|center|border]]
At the first session of the Constituent Assembly on 28 May, it voted to declare Nepal a federal democratic republic, thereby abolishing the monarchy. 564 members of the Constituent Assembly voted on this motion, with 560 in favor and four opposed.<ref name=Fed>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/may/may28/news18.php "Nepal becomes a federal democratic republic"], Nepalnews, May 28, 2008. {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160117050801/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/may/may28/news18.php |date=January 17, 2016 }}</ref> Of all the parties represented in the Constituent Assembly, only the [[Rastriya Prajatantra Party Nepal]] (RPP-Nepal) opposed the motion.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/may/may29/news01.php "RPP-Nepal becomes the only party against republic; some lawyers question procedures adopted by CA"]{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, May 29, 2008.</ref> Koirala said that Nepal was entering a new era and that "the nation's dream has come true", while celebrations took place in Kathmandu;<ref name=Abolishes>[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/0A9B5B1F-5BF2-4ACB-A159-700F21DAD3C4.htm "Nepal abolishes monarchy"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080530224530/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/0A9B5B1F-5BF2-4ACB-A159-700F21DAD3C4.htm |date=2008-05-30 }}, Al Jazeera, May 29, 2008.</ref> May 29 and May 30 were declared to be public holidays by the government.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/may/may28/news17.php "Govt announces two-day public holiday to celebrate republic"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, May 28, 2008.</ref> The Constituent Assembly also decided that Gyanendra should leave the [[Narayanhity Palace]] within 15 days.<ref name=Fed/>
Earlier on 28 May, the major parties agreed on the creation of the position of President, while the Prime Minister was to hold executive powers;<ref name=Fed/> however, they reached no agreement on exactly what powers the President should have or who should become President, and these deliberations led to a delay in the opening of the Constituent Assembly.<ref name=Post>Binaj Gurubacharya, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/05/29/AR2008052900820.html "Nepal assembly abolishes monarchy"], Associated Press (''The Washington Post''), May 29, 2008.</ref>
On 29 May, the royal standard was removed from Narayanhity Palace and replaced with the national flag.<ref name=Post/> Gyanendra reportedly said on 2 June that he accepted the Constituent Assembly's decision.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun02/news07.php "Ex-King Gyanendra says he accepts CA decision; prepares to leave Narayanhiti"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081007112957/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun02/news07.php |date=2008-10-07 }}, Nepalnews, June 2, 2008.</ref>
==Power-sharing discussions== 13 parties, including the CPN (M), the NC, and the CPN (UML), met at the Ministry of Peace and Reconstruction on June 1; no agreement was reached regarding power arrangements. The CPN (M) pressed its demand for both the positions of President and Prime Minister, but the NC and CPN (UML) were unwilling to accept this. The NC wanted these positions to be chosen through a simple majority vote in the Constituent Assembly.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun01/news10.php "13-party meeting inconclusive"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 1, 2008.</ref>
Addressing a rally in [[Gorkha district]] on June 1, Prachanda gave Koirala an ultimatum to present his resignation to the Constituent Assembly within two or three days, warning that if he failed to do so, the Maoist members of the government would resign and the party would lead street protests.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun01/news11.php "Prachanda gives three-day 'ultimatum' to NC to hand over govt's leadership"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 1, 2008.</ref>
After Gyanendra requested that the government make arrangements for his residence on June 1, the government decided on June 4 to give another palace, the [[Nagarjuna Palace]], to Gyanendra.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun04/news08.php "Govt decides to give Nagarjuna palace to ex-King"]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 4, 2008.</ref> Also on June 4, Prachanda and Koirala met; at this meeting Prachanda demanded that the government step aside by June 5 and again threatened street protests.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun03/news14.php "Prachanda meets Koirala; renews protest warning"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 3, 2008.</ref> On the same day, the three main parties held a meeting at which they again failed to reach an agreement, but the parties agreed on the need for a few more days and the CPN (M) postponed its deadline for the government to step aside to allow for this period.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun04/news12.php "Three parties agree to buy time; Maoists not to leave the govt"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 4, 2008.</ref>
On June 5, the CPN (M) softened its position, deciding at a meeting of its Central Secretariat that it would not press its claim to the presidency and that it would instead favor having a member of civil society become President. The party expressed continued opposition to a proposal that would allow the Prime Minister to be dismissed by a simple majority vote of the Constituent Assembly.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun05/news09.php "Maoists give up claim for presidency"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 5, 2008.</ref> Despite the Maoist desire to have a neutral figure as President, the NC proposed Koirala for the position.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun12/news04.php "NC, Maoists close to reaching agreement on govt formation"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 12, 2008.</ref>
The Constituent Assembly held its second sitting on June 5; due to the three major parties' deadlock, this sitting was very brief, lasting less than a half hour, and took no major decisions.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun05/news12.php "Second CA meeting ends without major decisions"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 5, 2008.</ref>
On June 11, Gyanendra gave a brief press conference at Narayanhiti, stating his acceptance of the republic and promising cooperation. He also said that he intended to stay in Nepal, asserted that he held no property outside of Nepal, and expressed his hope that he would be allowed to keep his property.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun11/news15.php "Ex-King holds press meet before leaving Narayanhiti; refutes allegations labeled against him; says he won't go into exile"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120185841/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun11/news15.php |date=2008-11-20 }}, Nepalnews, June 11, 2008.</ref> He left [[Narayanhiti]] on the same evening and went to his new residence at [[Nagarjuna]].<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun11/news16.php "Ex-King Gyanendra leaves Narayanhiti"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081007111955/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun11/news16.php |date=October 7, 2008 }}, Nepalnews, June 11, 2008.</ref>
Shortly after another meeting between Prachanda and Koirala, the CPN (M) ministers announced their resignations and sent a joint resignation letter to Prachanda on June 12.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun12/news10.php "Maoist ministers offer resignation"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110101084613/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun12/news10.php |date=2011-01-01 }}, Nepalnews, June 12, 2008.</ref> According to the CPN (M) Minister for Local Development, [[Dev Gurung]], the purpose of the resignations was to "accelerate the process of formation of a new government and bring an end to the current transitional period". However, some considered the resignations to be a means of increasing pressure on Koirala. The resignations were not immediately submitted to Koirala by the CPN (M), and therefore were not made effective. Gurung said that he expected a coalition government to be formed by June 18.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun13/news03.php "Coalition government by June 18: Minister Gurung"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 13, 2008.</ref>
Also on June 12, CPN (UML) General Secretary [[Jhala Nath Khanal]] asserted that a member of his party should become President.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun13/news01.php "UML also stakes claim to presidency"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 13, 2008.</ref> On June 14 he blamed the CPN (M) for the deadlock.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun14/news12.php "Khanal lays blame on the Maoists for delay in govt formation"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 14, 2008.</ref> At a meeting with [[Communist Party of Nepal (Marxist-Leninist) (2002)|Communist Party of Nepal (Marxist-Leninist)]] General Secretary [[C. P. Mainali]] on June 14, Koirala stressed the importance of power-sharing according to the popular mandate and consensus. Mainali expressed the view that the Maoists should be allowed to lead the government, while the post of President should go to someone from the [[Nepali Congress]] and the post of Chairman of the Constituent Assembly should go to someone from the CPN (UML).<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun14/news09.php "Power sharing should be on the basis of people's mandate, says Koirala"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 14, 2008.</ref> Meanwhile, Prachanda rejected the possibility of Koirala becoming President, saying that this would be a "dishonour to the people's mandate"; he also expressed concern that having Koirala as President could cause the development of a separate power center from the government, in addition to noting Koirala's advanced age and health problems. [[Prachanda]] said that the President should come from a smaller party rather than from the [[Nepali Congress]] or the CPN (UML).<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun15/news02.php "Maoist chief rules out Koirala's name from presidential race"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 15, 2008.</ref>
Koirala said on June 15 that he would not "run around pleading" for the presidency.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun15/news10.php "I won't plead before anyone for presidency, says PM"]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 15, 2008.</ref> [[Prachanda]], meanwhile, said that he expected the new government to be formed imminently, calling on other parties to support this and warning that anyone contravening the people's mandate would have a "heavy price" to pay.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun15/news11.php "Maoist chief asks parties to help them in formation of govt; warns them of consequences"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 15, 2008.</ref> Another meeting of the three main parties on June 16 ended in continued disagreement on the key issues,<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun16/news07.php "Three parties fail to reach consensus"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 16, 2008.</ref> and the CPN (M) said that it would submit the resignations of its ministers to Koirala if the next meeting on June 17 did not produce an agreement.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun16/news10.php "'CPN-M will pull out of govt if tomorrow's meeting ends in deadlock'"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 16, 2008.</ref>
CPN (UML) General Secretary Khanal said on June 17 that it was important for the left-wing parties to work together. While saying that the CPN (UML) and the CPN (M) would cooperate in the future, he noted that it would be necessary for the parties to improve their difficult relationship.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun17/news05.php "UML gen secy for left unity"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 17, 2008.</ref> The CPN (M) Central Secretariat met on the same day and approved the decision to hold firm on the key issues and for its ministers to resign if an agreement was not reached later in the day. The party chose to support [[Ramraja Prasad Singh]] for the presidency.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun17/news09.php "Maoists to be rigid on their stance; no to Koirala as president"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 17, 2008.</ref> [[Upendra Yadav]], the Coordinator of the Madhesi Janadhikar Forum, also said on June 17 that his party would not participate in the government and would instead be an opposition party, and he stressed the importance of cooperation among the Madhesi parties. Although he criticized the three main parties for focusing on their power struggle, he endorsed the Maoist claim to lead the government, while asserting that some of the key portfolios should be given to other parties.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun17/news13.php "MJF not to join govt"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 17, 2008.</ref>
The Constituent Assembly went into indefinite recess on June 18. The three main parties continued their discussions on that day, but did not reach an agreement. However, CPN (M) spokesman [[Krishna Bahadur Mahara]] said that they were getting closer to an agreement, and he said that the party had postponed its deadline to June 19.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun18/news13.php "Big three stumble over power-sharing; agree to continue talks"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 18, 2008.</ref>
On June 19, the three main parties reached an agreement providing for a constitutional amendment that would enable a government to be formed or dismissed by a simple majority vote of the Constituent Assembly, rather than the previously required two-thirds majority vote. An agreement was also concluded on the issue of integrating Maoist fighters into the national army. However, the parties did not yet agree on a way to resolve the question of power-sharing.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun19/news07.php "Big Three reach consensus on army integration, constitution amendment; Maoists back Sahana as presidential candidate"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 19, 2008.</ref> Later that day, the Seven-Party Alliance held a meeting at which Koirala said that he was prepared to resign at any time.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun19/news10.php "Koirala ready to step down; hints NC won't be part of next govt"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110102042530/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun19/news10.php |date=2011-01-02 }}, Nepalnews, June 19, 2008.</ref>
The CPN (M) and the CPN (UML) leadership met early on June 20, and afterwards Khanal said that the CPN (M) had "responded positively" to the CPN (UML)'s proposal to have someone from the CPN (UML) as President.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun20/news07.php "Maoists and UML cosy up on power-sharing; president for UML and PM for Maoists"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110101085053/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun20/news07.php |date=2011-01-01 }}, Nepalnews, June 20, 2008.</ref> A leading member of the CPN (UML) said that the two parties had agreed on the candidacy of [[Madhav Kumar Nepal]], the former General Secretary of the CPN (UML). However, a leading member of the CPN (M) disputed this, saying that the two parties were closer to an agreement but that their party had not agreed to support a CPN (UML) candidate; he said that both Nepal and [[Sahana Pradhan]] (whose name was proposed by the CPN (M)) had been discussed as candidates.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun21/news08.php "UML, Maoist leaders differ on presidential candidate"]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 21, 2008.</ref>
The [[Nepal Federation of Indigenous Nationalities]] (NFIN) met with Koirala on June 20, seeking a recommendation that indigenous peoples not already represented in the Constituent Assembly be included in it through the 26 nominated seats. Koirala, who was supportive of the NFIN's request, also sharply criticized his rivals on this occasion, saying that they were practicing petty politics and were not respecting the people's mandate to work on a consensus basis.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun20/news08.php "PM Koirala miffed by petty politics"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 20, 2008.</ref> The Maoist ministers submitted their joint resignation at a meeting of the seven parties on June 20.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun20/news12.php "Maoist ministers tender resignation at seven party meeting"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110101021230/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun20/news12.php |date=2011-01-01 }}, Nepalnews, June 20, 2008.</ref>
[[Sher Bahadur Deuba]] of the Nepali Congress said on June 24 that the CPN (M) was responsible for the deadlock and claimed that it was working to divide the Seven-Party Alliance. He also said that Koirala would resign after the election of a President and that the CPN (M) had no authority to demand his resignation before then.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun24/news09.php "Deuba blames Maoists for SPA breakdown"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 24, 2008.</ref> Also on June 24, the seven parties agreed on the introduction of a constitutional amendment providing for the election of a President and the formation of a government through simple majority votes. There was, however, disagreement over the Nepali Congress proposal to include a member of the opposition on the National Security Council; the CPN (M) and the CPN (UML) described this as undemocratic. There was also a proposal to include members of each of the seven parties on the National Security Council.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun24/news12.php "Parties discuss constitution amendment; preparing to introduce a bill in CA"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 24, 2008.</ref> Despite the failure to agree about the opposition's inclusion on the National Security Council, it was agreed to give the opposition a place on the Constitutional Council. The parties also reached agreement on a number of issues related to peace, disarmament and reintegration.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun25/news02.php "Govt to introduce Fifth Amendment proposal today"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, June 25, 2008.</ref> A decision was also reached with to divide the 26 nominated seats in the Constituent Assembly among nine parties: the CPN (M) was to receive nine of these seats, while the Nepali Congress and the CPN (UML) would each receive five, the [[Madhesi Janadhikar Forum]] would receive two, and the [[Sadbhavana Party]], the [[Nepal Workers and Peasants Party]], [[Janamorcha Nepal]], and the [[Communist Party of Nepal-Marxist Leninist]] would each receive one nominated seat.<ref name="CabAmend"/>
==Resignation of Koirala, Madhesi demands== The Council of Ministers approved the constitutional amendment late on June 25.<ref name=CabAmend/> At a meeting of the Constituent Assembly on June 26, Koirala announced his resignation, although it will not be finalized until after the election of a President, to whom the resignation must be submitted.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun26/news09.php "Prime Minister announces his resignation"]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 26, 2008.</ref> Although it was expected that the constitutional amendment would be approved at the same meeting, it was not introduced after Madhesi members of the Constituent Assembly demanded that the amendment be expanded to incorporate a March 2008 agreement between the Madhesis and the government that provided for Madhesi autonomy, among other things. As a result of this, the Constituent Assembly meeting was suspended until June 28.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun26/news10.php "CA meeting suspended after Madhesi party members demand withdrawal of amendment bill; next meeting on Saturday"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 26, 2008.</ref> After meeting with Koirala on June 27, [[Hridayesh Tripathy]] of the [[Terai Madhes Loktantrik Party]] (TMLP) said that Koirala was in favor of incorporating the Madhesi agreement into the amendment and that he asked the Madhesis not to disrupt the Constituent Assembly again.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun27/news12.php "PM Koirala assures Madhesi leaders of fulfilling their demands"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 27, 2008.</ref>
On June 28, the seven parties met to discuss the Madhesi demands; although no decision was reached, all of the parties opposed the Madhesi demand for a single province. The Constituent Assembly met later that day and was again disrupted by representatives of the Madhesi parties, forcing the cancellation of the meeting after only a few minutes.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun28/news06.php "Terai parties again obstruct CA proceeding; next CA meeting Sunday afternoon"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 28, 2008.</ref> The next Constituent Assembly meeting on June 29 was also disrupted by the Madhesis and was cancelled.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun29/news09.php "CA stalemate continues"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 29, 2008.</ref> Jaya Prakash Gupta, a leading figure in the [[Madhesi Janadhikar Forum]] (MJF), also warned on June 29 that the Madhesi parties would "not only obstruct the Constituent Assembly but also paralyse the entire nation to force [the seven parties] to meet our demands."<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun29/news12.php "Gupta threatens to paralyse the entire country if Madhesi demands are not met"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 29, 2008.</ref> Prachanda, in an interview on June 30, expressed frustration with the Madhesi parties' disruption, which occurred just after Koirala's resignation, when it appeared the road to forming a new government was clear. He said that he favored Madhesi autonomy, but opposed their demand for all of [[Terai]] to become one Madhesi province.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun30/news07.php "Maoist chief blames Terai parties for delay in govt formation"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 30, 2008.</ref> Khanal, the CPN (UML) General Secretary, flatly rejected the demand for a single Madhesi province, condemning it as "a game to disintegrate the nation". He said that the demand ignored the wishes of other ethnic groups in the Terai.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun30/news09.php "'One Madhesh' demand is a threat to national integrity, says Khanal"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 30, 2008.</ref>
The Constituent Assembly met on June 30 but was again disrupted by the Madhesis and the meeting was cancelled.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jun/jun30/news11.php "Terai parties obstruct CA meeting for fourth time in a row"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, June 30, 2008.</ref> The three main parties reached an agreement with the three Madhesi parties, the MJF, the TMLP, and the Nepal Sadbhavana Party, on July 1, providing for a supplementary amendment bill that would meet the Madhesi demands.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul01/news09.php "Six parties agree to introduce supplementary amendment bill to resolve CA deadlock"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, July 1, 2008.</ref> Another meeting of the Constituent Assembly was disrupted by the Madhesis and aborted on July 2, while the CPN (M), [[Nepali Congress]], and CPN (UML) met to decide the draft text of the supplementary amendment bill.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul02/news12.php "No end yet to CA stalemate"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081122025944/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul02/news12.php |date=2008-11-22 }}, Nepalnews, July 2, 2008.</ref>
The CPN (M) and MJF met on July 3, and the CPN (M) agreed to include a reference to Madhesi autonomy in the bill, while also saying that it wanted the bill to mention other indigenous groups' desire for autonomy.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul03/news09.php "Maoists 'agree' to address Madhesi demands in supplementary bill"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081122025611/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul03/news09.php |date=2008-11-22 }}, Nepalnews, July 3, 2008.</ref> 13 small parties in the Constituent Assembly said on July 3 that they were completely opposed to the Madhesi demand for a single autonomous province, and they criticized the larger parties for the political deadlock that prevented discussion of the issues from taking place in the Constituent Assembly.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul04/news02.php "Smaller parties up in arms over CA imbroglio"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012211656/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul04/news02.php |date=2008-10-12 }}, Nepalnews, July 4, 2008.</ref>
Sessions of the Constituent Assembly were attempted on July 3 and July 4, but both were immediately disrupted by the Madhesi members and were aborted. On the latter occasion, [[Kul Bahadur Gurung]], who chaired the session, urged the Madhesi members to respect the right of other members to be heard, but they ignored him.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul04/news07.php "CA session disrupted again"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081007113536/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul04/news07.php |date=2008-10-07 }}, Nepalnews, July 4, 2008.</ref> On July 4, the CPN (M), Nepali Congress, and CPN (UML) agreed on a draft supplementary amendment bill intended to satisfy the Madhesi demands. The draft requires the State Restructuring Commission to consider the March 2008 agreement between the government and the Madhesis when drawing up Nepal's federal structure. A meeting of the Seven Party Alliance followed the three-party agreement, and at this meeting, the [[People's Front Nepal]], United Left Front, and [[Nepal Workers and Peasants Party]] objected to the draft, saying that it would endanger national unity.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul04/news08.php "Big Three reach consensus; minor allies oppose draft supplementary bill"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080906162104/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul04/news08.php |date=2008-09-06 }}, Nepalnews, July 4, 2008.</ref> The cabinet approved the bill late on July 4; at the same time, it decided to nominate the 26 remaining members of the Constituent Assembly, dividing the seats between nine parties in accordance with the parties' earlier agreement and the lists of names they presented.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul04/news13.php "Cabinet endorses supplementary bill; nominates 26 CA members"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828051018/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul04/news13.php |date=2008-08-28 }}, Nepalnews, July 4, 2008.</ref>
The Madhesi parties quickly deemed the supplementary amendment bill to be an unacceptable "betrayal".<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul05/news02.php "Madhesi parties conclude govt has betrayed them"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081122042501/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul05/news02.php |date=2008-11-22 }}, Nepalnews, July 5, 2008.</ref> Khanal, the CPN (UML) General Secretary, said that the bill should satisfy the Madhesi demands, and he warned that opposition to the bill would not be in Madhesi interests or in the interests of any of the peoples of Terai. He called on the Madhesi members to make proposals and engage in discussion in the Constituent Assembly instead of disrupting it.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul06/news04.php "Terai parties will suffer major set back if they oppose bill: UML gen secy"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828050223/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul06/news04.php |date=2008-08-28 }}, Nepalnews, July 6, 2008.</ref>
On July 6, at a meeting between the three main parties and the Madhesi parties, the former agreed to formulate a new bill to replace the one agreed upon two days prior, while the latter agreed to stop disrupting the Constituent Assembly.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul06/news09.php "Three parties agree to bring new amendment bill; Madhesi parties to allow CA to function"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081122033235/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul06/news09.php |date=2008-11-22 }}, Nepalnews, July 6, 2008.</ref> 23 of the 26 nominated members of the Constituent Assembly were sworn in on July 7; the remaining three were unable to attend the swearing in ceremony.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul07/news05.php "23 new CA members sworn in"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828045747/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul07/news05.php |date=2008-08-28 }}, Nepalnews, July 7, 2008.</ref> On July 8, the Seven Party Alliance, with the exception of the [[Nepal Workers and Peasants Party]], agreed on the content of a new draft bill, according to which federal structures would be created in line with the wishes of the Madhesis and other ethnic groups.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul08/news06.php "Six parties reach consensus on supplementary bill"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828052459/http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul08/news06.php |date=2008-08-28 }}, Nepalnews, July 8, 2008.</ref>
The Constituent Assembly was able to meet and function on July 9, for the first time since the Madhesis began pressing their demands on June 26.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul09/news10.php "CA proceedings resume finally"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, July 9, 2008.</ref> Although they did not disrupt the Constituent Assembly on this occasion, the three Madhesi parties furiously condemned the proposed bill and vowed that their struggle would continue.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul09/news13.php "Madhesi leaders spit venom at supplementary bill"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, July 9, 2008.</ref> During the Constituent Assembly meeting, they submitted a protest notice, and when this was rejected, they chose to boycott the Constituent Assembly's proceedings. [[Narendra Bikram Nemwang]], the Minister for Law, Justice and Parliamentary Affairs, tabled the bill regardless.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul10/news02.php "Govt tables amendment bill; Madhesis boycott"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, July 10, 2008.</ref>
Koirala said on July 11 that forming a government was the responsibility of the CPN (M).<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul11/news09.php "Maoists responsible for formation of new govt: PM Koirala"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, July 11, 2008.</ref> However, the CPN (M) criticized the Nepali Congress on July 12 for "obstructing the process [of forming a government] for the past three months".<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul13/news01.php "Maoists blame NC for delay in govt formation"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, July 13, 2008.</ref> To protest the amendment bill, the Madhesi parties boycotted the Constituent Assembly meeting held on July 13, at which the amendment bill was considered.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul13/news07.php "Madhesi parties boycott CA meeting"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, July 13, 2008.</ref> The bill was passed on the same day; 442 members of the Constituent Assembly voted for the amendment and seven voted against it. It thus became the interim constitution's Fifth Amendment. The amendment allows for the formation of a government based on a Constituent Assembly majority; it also allows the President, Vice-President, Chairman of the Constituent Assembly, and the Deputy Chairman of the Constituent Assembly to be elected by majority vote if there is no consensus. In addition, the amendment provides for the Leader of the Opposition to become a member of the Constitutional Council; however, the Constituent Assembly rejected a proposal from the cabinet that the Leader of the Opposition be included on the National Defense Council.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul14/news01.php "Fifth Amendment passed; coast cleared for forming majority govt"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, July 14, 2008.</ref>
In a meeting with the Nepali Congress on July 14, the CPN (M) urged it to participate in the new government. A Nepali Congress leader replied that the party had still not decided whether to participate.<ref>[http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul14/news09.php "Maoists ask NC to join next govt"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Nepalnews, July 14, 2008.</ref>
==Election of Nepal's first president== {{main|Nepalese presidential election, 2008}} An indirect presidential election was held in [[Nepal]] on 19 July 2008 with a presidential run-off on 21 July. The Nepalese Constituent Assembly (CA) [[Nepalese Constituent Assembly election, 2008|elected in April 2008]] elected a new President and Vice-President after the Fifth Amendment to the Interim Constitution was passed on July 14.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul14/news01.php|title=CA to Elect President on July 19|date=2008-07-14|publisher=Nepal News|accessdate=2008-07-21}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> This would be the first President to be elected after Nepal became a republic a few months earlier.
In the newly passed amendment, the majority party will form the government, the CA will elect the new President on the basis of majority and a new provision that the Opposition Leader will be a member of the Constitutional Council.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nepalnews.com/archive/2008/jul/jul14/news01.php|title=Fifth Amendment Passed; Coast Cleared for Forming Majority Govt|date=2008-07-14|publisher=Nepal News|accessdate=2008-07-21}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The leading political parties, [[Nepali Congress]], [[Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist)]] and [[Communist Party of Nepal (United Marxist-Leninist)]] engaged in discussions regarding who would be the new President. The Nepali Congress wanted Prime Minister and interim Head of State [[Girija Prasad Koirala]] while the Communist Party of Nepal (United Marxist-Leninist) wanted its former Secretary-General [[Madhav Kumar Nepal]] as President. However, the Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist) wants an independent figure as President rather than party figures such as Koirala or Nepal. The Maoists won the most seats in the CA however needs to form a coalition government with the other parties.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2008/07/15/asia/AS-Nepal-Politics.php|title=Nepal's Top Political Parties Begin Search for Country's First President|date=2008-07-15|publisher=International Herald Tribune|accessdate=2008-07-21}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=February 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} The '''Decision of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress on Issues Relating to the Selection of the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region by Universal Suffrage and on the Method for Forming the Legislative Council of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region in the Year 2016''' ({{zh-t|2016}}), commonly known as '''31 August Decision''' ({{zh-t|}}), is a decision made by the [[Standing Committee of the National People's Congress]] (NPCSC), the national legislative body of the [[People's Republic of China]] (PRC) on 31 August 2014 which set limits for the [[Hong Kong Chief Executive election, 2017|2017 Chief Executive election]] and [[Hong Kong legislative election, 2016|2016 Legislative Council election]] in the [[Hong Kong Special Administrative Region]] (HKSAR).
The decision states that a [[Hong Kong Chief Executive]] candidate has to "love the country and love Hong Kong". For the 2017 Chief Executive election, a nominating committee, similar to the present [[Election Committee]] system, be formed to nominate two to three candidates, each of whom must receive the support of more than half of the members of the nominating committee. After popular election of one of the nominated candidates, the new Chief Executive "will have to be appointed by the [[Central People's Government]]." The process of forming the 2016 Legislative Council would be unchanged, but following the new process for the election of the Chief Executive, a new system to elect the Legislative Council via universal suffrage would be developed with the approval of Beijing.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2014-08/31/c_133609238.htm | title=Full text of NPC decision on universal suffrage for HKSAR chief selection | agency=Xinhua News Agency | date=31 August 2014 | accessdate=31 August 2014}}</ref> The decision was deemed by the [[pro-democracy camp|pro-democracy activists]] as a violation of the principle of free and fair election and led to the [[2014 Hong Kong protests|large-scale occupation protests]] which was internationally known as "Umbrella Revolution".
==Background== {{main|201415 Hong Kong electoral reform}} In December 2013, the Hong Kong government launched a public consultative over the electoral method of the [[Hong Kong Chief Executive election, 2017|2017 Chief Executive election]] and [[Hong Kong legislative election, 2016|2016 Legislative Council election]]. According to the Decision of the [[Standing Committee of the National People's Congress]] (NPCSC) in 2007, the 2017 Chief Executive election "may be implemented by the method of universal suffrage".<ref>{{cite book|title=Methods for Selecting the Chief Executive in 2017 and for Forming the Legislative Council in 2016 Consultation Document|author =The Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government|year=2013|p=3|ref=harv|url=http://www.legco.gov.hk/yr13-14/english/panels/ca/papers/ca1209-cdoc20131204-e.pdf}}</ref> After a period of consultation ran from December 2013 to May 2014, which the issues centred on whether the Chief Executive has to "love the Country and love Hong Kong" and the role of a nominating committee as stated in [[Hong Kong Basic Law Article 45]] "the selection of the Chief Executive by universal suffrage upon nomination by a broadly representative nominating committee in accordance with democratic procedures."<ref name="HKbasicalaw">HK basic law web pdf. "[http://www.info.gov.hk/basic_law/fulltext/Basic_Law.pdf HK basic law]." ''The Basic Law of the Hong Kong Special Administrative region of the People's Republic of China.'' Retrieved on 8 January 2007.</ref>
As early in March 2013, [[Qiao Xiaoyang]], chairman of the Law Committee under the NPCSC, stated that Chief Executive candidates must be persons who love the country and love Hong Kong, who do not insist on confronting the central government. Observers stated that Qiao comment was to screen out candidates from the opposition pro-democracy camp.<ref name="25/3/13">{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/article/1199015/opposition-camp-members-cant-run-chief-executive-says-npc-official|newspaper=[[South China Morning Post]]|last1=Lee|first1=Colleen|last2=But|first2=Joshua|title=Opponents of Beijing ineligible to be CE: top Chinese official|date=25 March 2013}}</ref> Qiao also mentioned that "the nominating committee is in fact an organisation. The nomination of Chief Executive candidates by the nominating committee is a form of organisational nomination.{{sfn|The Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government|2013|p=3}}
On 22 November 2013, Li Fei, Qiao's successor as NPCSC Law Committee chairman, stated that "the Chief Executive is accountable to the central government as well as Hong Kong. This means that the post must be taken up by a person who loves the country as well as Hong Kong anyone opposed to the central government cannot [take it]."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1363262/catch-22-situation-looms-over-election-chief-executive-2017?page=all|newspaper=South China Morning Post|last1= Cheung |first1=Tony|last2=Chong|first2=Tanna|title=Catch-22 situation looms over election for chief executive in 2017|date=22 November 2013}}</ref>
After the first consultation period ended in May, the Consultation Report was published in July 2014. Following that [[Chief Executive of Hong Kong|Chief Executive]] [[Leung Chun-ying]] submitted the ''Report by the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region to the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress''. The public generally speculated that the NPCSC would set the framework of the electoral reform in the meeting in coming August.
==Provisions== On 31 August 2014, the Tenth Session of the Standing Committee of the Twelfth National People's Congress adopted the Decision on selecting method of the 2017 Chief Executive and 2016 Legislative Council elections:
The Decision states that "the principle that the Chief Executive has to be a person who loves the country and loves Hong Kong must be upheld." The selecting method of the Chief Executive has to be framed institutionally to maintain long-term prosperity and stability of Hong Kong and uphold the sovereignty, security and development interests of the country.<ref name="decision">{{cite web|title=Decision of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress on Issues Relating to the Selection of the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region by Universal Suffrage and on the Method for Forming the Legislative Council of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region in the Year 2016|url=http://www.2017.gov.hk/filemanager/template/en/doc/20140831b.pdf|author= Tenth Session of the Standing Committee of the Twelfth National People's Congress|date=31 August 2014}}</ref>
It also states that a broadly representative nominating committee shall be formed, in which the number of members, composition and formation method of the nominating committee shall be made in accordance to the existing [[Election Committee]] formed in 2012.<ref name="decision"/> The nominating committee shall nominate two to three candidates, in which each candidate must have the endorsement of more than half of all the members of the nominating committee before all eligible voters can vote in the election.<ref name="decision"/>
The Chief Executive-elect, after being selected through universal suffrage, will have to be appointed by the [[Central People's Government]].<ref name="decision"/>
The formation method and procedures for voting on bills and motions of the [[5th Legislative Council of Hong Kong|5th Legislative Council]] will continue to apply to the [[6th Legislative Council of Hong Kong|6th Legislative Council]] in 2016. After the election of the Chief Executive by universal suffrage, the election of all the members of the Legislative Council may be implemented by the method of universal suffrage.<ref name="decision"/>
==Reactions== {{see also|2014 Hong Kong class boycott campaign|2014 Hong Kong protests}} The Hong Kong government welcomed the NPCSC decision. Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying said that "the majority of Hong Kong citizens, namely, the 5 million qualified voters of the selection of Chief Executive in 2017, will be able to cast their votes to select the chief executive." He also said "this is the first opportunity a very good opportunity for Hong Kong to have one man, one vote universal suffrage. This is something we should all feel proud of."<ref name="CNN">{{cite news|title=Beijing says no to open elections in Hong Kong|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2014/08/31/world/asia/hong-kong-elections/|work=CNN|date=5 September 2014}}</ref>
The [[Occupy Central with Love and Peace]] movement who had vowed to launched a massive [[civil obedience]] [[Occupation (protest)|occupation]] at the city centre of [[Central, Hong Kong]] if the constitutional reform proposals did not reach the international standard of free and fair election slammed Beijing's decision as a move that stifles democracy and blocks people with different political views from running for office. "Genuine universal suffrage includes both the rights to elect and to be elected," its statement said. "The decision of the NPC Standing Committee has deprived people with different political views of the right to run for election and be elected by imposing unreasonable restrictions, thereby perpetuating 'handpicked politics.'"<ref name="CNN"/> It said it would go on with their Occupy Central plan in the rally where several thousand people turned out opposing Beijing's plan on 31 August night. Occupy Central co-founder [[Benny Tai]] told the crowd, "our hope is that people gathered here will be dauntless civil resisters. What is our hope? Our hope is that today Hong Kong has entered a new era, an era of civil disobedience, an era of resistance."<ref name="NYT">{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/01/world/asia/hong-kong-elections.html | title=China Restricts Voting Reforms for Hong Kong | work=The New York Times | date=31 August 2014 | accessdate=31 August 2014 |author1=Buckley, Chris |author2=Forsythe, Michael}}</ref>
The [[Pro-democracy camp in Hong Kong|pan-democracy camp]] saw it as the method to screen out the opposition candidates as the pan-democrat candidates would not get a majority support from the nominating committee if its composition mirrors the existing [[Election Committee]] which dominated by pro-Beijing interests. The pan-democrat candidates were able to enter the Chief Executive elections by getting just one-eighth of the nomination threshold from the Election Committee. There were also some interpretations that an organisational nomination would be a breach of the Basic Law.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=South China Morning Post|title='Collective nomination' does not accord with Basic Law|date=22 December 2013}}</ref> The [[Democratic Party (Hong Kong)|Democratic Party]] vowed to "veto this revolting proposal."<ref name="NYT"/>
The largest student organisation [[Hong Kong Federation of Students]] (HKFS) and student activist group [[Scholarism]] urged university and secondary school students to [[2014 Hong Kong class boycott campaign|boycott classes]] opposing the NPCSC decision and also organised public events, including street assemblies. The student movement evolved into the 79-day [[2014 Hong Kong protests|large-scale occupy movement]] internationally known as "Umbrella Revolution". The retraction of the NPCSC decision became one of the main goals of the protesters. On 28 October, the HKFS issued an open letter to the Chief Secretary Carrie Lam asking for a second round of talks. HKFS set out a prerequisite for the negotiation, that the government's report to the Chinese government must include a call for the retraction of the NPCSC's decision. The government refused the demand, stating that the political reform has to be bounded by the NPCSC decision .<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.hkej.com/instantnews/current/article/924148/%E5%AD%B8%E8%81%AF%E7%99%BC%E5%85%AC%E9%96%8B%E4%BF%A1+%E6%8F%90%E5%B0%8D%E8%A9%B1%E4%BA%8C%E5%89%8D%E6%8F%90%28%E9%99%84%E5%85%A8%E6%96%87%29|script-title=zh: |trans-title=Federation of Students sends a letter naming two prerequisites|work=Hong Kong Economic Journal |language=zh|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref>
In an opinion poll carried out by Chinese University of Hong Kong, only 36.1% of 802 people surveyed between 815 October accept NPCSC's decision but 55.6% are willing to accept if the HKSAR Government would democratise the nominating committee during the second phase of public consultation period.<ref name=cuhksurvey>{{cite web|url=http://www.com.cuhk.edu.hk/ccpos/images/news/20141022-eng.pdf |title=Public Opinion & Political Development in Hong Kong Survey Results (Press Release) October 22, 2014 |accessdate=5 September 2016 |publisher=Chinese University of Hong Kong |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6VtHssHnm?url=http://www.com.cuhk.edu.hk/ccpos/images/news/20141022-eng.pdf |archivedate=27 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Aftermath== On 7 January 2015, the Hong Kong government launched a two-month public consultation after the delay due to the protests. The pan-democracy camp boycotted the consultation in protest against the NPCSC decision.
On 31 May 2015, three top Beijing officials, Basic Law Committee chairman Li Fei, [[Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office]] director [[Wang Guangya]] and [[Liaison Office of the Central People's Government in Hong Kong]] director [[Zhang Xiaoming]] met with members of the Legislative Council in Shenzhen including pan-democracy legislators. The Beijing officials dashed any hope of last-minute concessions from Beijing with tough stances during the four-hour talk and the post-meeting press conference. Li also stressed that the framework set down on 31 August would govern the election of Hong Kong's leader by universal suffrage in 2017 and onwards.<ref>{{cite news|title=Beijing officials get tough with pan-democrats over Hong Kong electoral reform stance|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/1814340/beijing-officials-get-tough-pan-democrats-over-electoral|first1=Gary|last1=Cheung|first2=Tony|last2=Cheung|first3=Jeffie|last3=Lam|newspaper=South China Morning Post|date=1 June 2015}}</ref> The pan-democrats said they would definitely veto the political reform package as the meeting with mainland officials left them with no choice.<ref>{{cite news|title=No choice but to veto proposal|date=1 June 2015|newspaper=The Standard|url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?we_cat=11&art_id=157480&sid=44580379&con_type=1&d_str=20150601&fc=1|first=Kenneth|last=Lau}}</ref>
On 18 June 2015, the [[Legislative Council of Hong Kong|Legislative Council]] rejected the unmodified electoral reform proposal with 8 votes in favour, 28 against, and 33 not voting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/06/18/asia/hong-kong-reform-vote/index.html|title=Hong Kong legislators reject China-backed reform bill|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=19 June 2015|accessdate=19 June 2015}}</ref>
The pan-democrats have been calling for the NPCSC decision to be shelved, but pro-Beijing politicians had said the decision would be still relevant after 2017. It also became one of the key issues in the [[Hong Kong Chief Executive election, 2017|2017 Chief Executive election]], in which the pro-democrats pressured the candidates to relaunch the constitutional reform without the 831 basis.
